questions.question:
Question 1: The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by  
.
questions.explanation:
The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by Caldwell and Moloy. 52 
Sold by @itachibot The greatest transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet divides the pelvis into anterior and posterior 
segments. The shapes of these segments help classify the pelvis as follows: • Gynecoid • Anthropoid • Android • Platypelloid The various differences between these types is summarised below: Gynecoid

questions.question:
Question 2: An obese woman with dysmenorrhea and irregular periods is diagnosed with dystocia 
dystrophia syndrome. What type of pelvis is seen here?
questions.explanation:
In dystocia dystrophia syndrome, an android pelvis is seen. Dystocia dystrophia syndrome: • The patient is stockily built with a bull neck, broad shoulders, and short thighs. She is obese with 
a male distribution of hair. • Subfertile, with dysmenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, or irregular periods. • There is an increased incidence of pre-eclampsia and a tendency for postmaturity. • The pelvis is of the android type. The occipito-posterior position is common. • During labor, there is a tendency for deep transverse arrest or outlet dystocia, leading to difficult 
instrumental delivery or cesarean section. • There is a chance of lactation failure.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is false about anthropoid pelvis?
questions.explanation:
The anthropoid pelvis has straight side walls, not convergent side walls. Given below are the differences between various types of pelvis as per Caldwell-Moloy

questions.question:
Question 4: A 28-year-old term primigravida gave birth to a male baby by face to pubis delivery. Which 
type of pelvis is this mode of delivery commonly seen with?
questions.explanation:
Face to pubis delivery is most commonly associated with anthropoid pelvis. As the anthropoid pelvis is wider posteriorly, the fetal occiput occupies the posterior segment of 
the pelvis. Thus, the fetus is present in the occipitoposterior position which leads to a high chance 
of face-to-pubis delivery. 55 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: An obstetrician performing clinical pelvimetry finds that the smallest transverse diameter is 8 
cm. Which of the following parameters has she assessed?
questions.explanation:
The interspinous diameter is the smallest transverse pelvic diameter. The interspinous diameter or bispinous diameter is measured in the mid pelvis. It is the distance 
between the tips of two ischial spines. Normally, it is 10-10.5 cm. It is useful in predicting obstructed labor. If the interspinous diameter is too small, the baby's 
head may get stuck at a higher station. Note: The obstetric conjugate is the smallest anteroposterior pelvic diameter measuring 10 cm. 56 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: During clinical pelvimetry, the obstetrician determines the diagonal conjugate to be X cm. 
What is the obstetric conjugate?
questions.explanation:
The obstetric conjugate is X-2cm where X is the diagonal conjugate. Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvis: • True conjugate or the anteroposterior diameter, extends from the upper most margin of the 
symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. It is normally 11 cm. • Obstetrical conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis 
pubis. It is normally 10 cm. It is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal 
conjugate. • Diagonal conjugate is determined by measuring the distance from the lowest margin of the 
symphysis to the sacral promontory. It is normally 12cm. It is measured clinically.

questions.question:
Question 7: A diabetic primigravida is suspected to have cephalopelvic disproportion. What should her 
obstetric conjugate be for a trial of labor to be conducted?
questions.explanation:
In the given case scenario, a trial of labor or vaginal delivery can be allowed if the obstetric 
conjugate is 10cm or more. The obstetric conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis 
pubis. Normally, it is 10 cm or more. The diagonal conjugate measures 12cm and the true conjugate measures 11cm. Clinically, only the diagonal conjugate is assessed by measuring the distance between the base of 
the examiner's fingers and the fingertip touching the sacral promontory. This determines 
the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory. The obstetric conjugate is estimated 
indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate. Note: Overt diabetes can cause fetal macrosomia during pregnancy. Thus, it may lead to 
cephalopelvic disproportion. 57 
Sold by @itachibot Given below is an image of the lateral plane in CT pelvimetry, showing the anteroposterior 
diameters of the pelvis. Line no. 4 is the obstetric conjugate and line no. 5 is the pelvic outlet.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following parameters cannot be viewed in lateral plate X-ray pelvimetry?
questions.explanation:
The bispinous diameter can be viewed in the anteroposterior view and not the lateral plate 
pelvimetry. X-ray pelvimetry is done using 3 views: • Anteroposterior - Transverse diameter and bispinous diameter is determined. • Lateral - Obstetric conjugate, sacral curve and pelvic inclination are seen. • Outlet - Outlet diameters are determined. 58 
Sold by @itachibot Note: CT pelvimetry is preferred over X-ray pelvimetry due to the lower dose of radiation 
delivered. Given below are images of CT pelvimetry, anteroposterior and lateral views respectively. The 
marked diameters are as follows: 2 - Interspinous diameter 3 - Intertuberous diameter 4 - Obstetric conjugate 5 - Pelvic outlet

questions.question:
Question 9: A P1A1 woman with a history of obstructed labor is being evaluated for a contracted pelvis. 
CT pelvis shows both sacral alae are absent. What is the type of pelvis seen here?
questions.explanation:
59 
Sold by @itachibot The type of pelvis seen here is Robert's pelvis. In it, the pelvis is transversely contracted and the 
ala on both sides are absent and the sacrum is fused with the innominate bones. Option A: In Naegele's pelvis, there is arrested development of one ala of the sacrum. Option C: Kyphotic pelvis occurs secondary to the kyphotic changes of the vertebral column either 
following tuberculosis or rickets. Option D: In rachitic pelvis, due to softening of bones, flattening of the pelvis occurs.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient with prolonged second stage of labor is referred to the district hospital. You suspect 
her to have a contracted pelvis. Which of the following is true about this condition?

options.a: Transverse diameter of inlet is 10 cm
options.b: Anteroposterior diameter of inlet is 12 cm
options.c: Transverse diameter of inlet is 12 cm
options.d: Anteroposterior diameter of inlet is 14 cm

questions.explanation:
To make a diagnosis of contracted pelvis, the transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet should be 
10cm. The pelvic inlet is considered to be contracted if: • the greatest transverse diameter is < 12 cm or • the shortest anteroposterior diameter is < 10 cm. The anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet are the true conjugate, diagonal conjugate and 
obstetric conjugate. These extend between the sacral promontory and symphysis pubis. The 
obstetric conjugate is the shortest diameter, normally measuring 10 cm. The transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet is at a right angle to the obstetric conjugate. It extends 
between the linea terminalis on either side. Normally, the transverse diameter is about 13 cm. 60 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is the smallest diameter of the fetal head?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, the bitemporal diameter is the smallest. It is the distance between the 
anteroinferior ends of the coronal suture and usually measures 8 cm. This is the smallest engaging 
diameter. Option A: The biparietal diameter is a transverse diameter between two parietal eminences, 
measuring 9.5cm. Option B: The suboccipitofrontal diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 10 cm. Option C: The suboccipitobregmatic diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 9.5 cm. Note: The bimastoid diameter is a transverse diameter. It is the smallest diameter in the fetal skull 
at about 7.5 cm. However it is not clinically relevant as it does not engage.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 32-year-old woman in labor is referred to a tertiary care center. On PV examination, the 
resident notes that the fetus is in brow presentation, and the largest diameter of the fetal skull 50 
Sold by @itachibot is engaged. Identify this diameter.
questions.explanation:
In brow presentation, the mentovertical diameter is engaged which is the longest diameter of the 
fetal skull. Normally, it measures 14 cm. The mentovertical diameter extends from the midpoint of the chin to the highest point on the 
sagittal suture. Engaging diameters of the fetal skull vary with the attitude of the fetal head as given below: Diameters 
Attitude of the hea 
d Complete flexion Suboccipitobregma 
tic 61 
Sold by @itachibot Diameters 
Attitude of the hea 
d Suboccipito-frontal 
Incomplete flexion Occipitofrontal 
Marked deflexion Mento-vertical 
Partial extension Submentovertical 
Incomplete extensi 
on Complete extension Submentobregmati 
c

questions.question:
Question 13: A G6P5L5 woman presented to the casualty with abdominal pain. The PV examination 
findings are given below. What is the engaging diameter?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the engaging diameter is the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter. It is 
engaged when the fetus is in vertex presentation with an attitude of complete flexion of the head. The table given below shows the engaging diameter with each attitude of the fetal head. Diameters 
Attitude of the hea 
d Complete flexion Suboccipitobregma 
tic Suboccipito-frontal 
Incomplete flexion Occipitofrontal 
Marked deflexion Mento-vertical 
Partial extension Submentovertical 
Incomplete extensi 
on Complete extension Submentobregmati 
c

questions.question: Question 14: How many fontanelles are present in a newborn?
questions.explanation:
Newborns have a total of 6 fontanelles. These are fibrous, membrane-covered gaps between 
cranial bones. The fontanelles seen in newborns are: • Anterior fontanelle: • It is also called bregma. • Diameter ranges from 0.6-3.6 cm, with a mean of 2.1 cm. • It completely closes by 24 months of age. • Posterior fontanelle: 62 
Sold by @itachibot • It is also called lambda. • Diameter ranges from 0.5-0.7 cm. • It completely closes by 2 months of age. • 2 sphenoid fontanelles • 2 mastoid fontanelles Note: A third fontanelle between the anterior and posterior fontanels is associated with 
hypothyroidism and Down's syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 24-year-old primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by assisted forceps delivery. The 
next day, you note a swelling over the infant's head that is limited by suture lines. Which of 
the following is true regarding the swelling?

options.a: Tension in the swelling varies on crying

questions.explanation:
In the given clinical picture, the swelling over the infant's head is likely to be a cephalhematoma. 
Infants with cephalohematomas are at a heightened risk of developing jaundice because as the 
blood breaks down, the levels of bilirubin increase. Cephalohematoma is a collection of blood in between the pericranium and the flat bone 
(subperiosteal) of the skull, usually unilateral and over a parietal bone.It is never present at birth 
but gradually develops after 12–24 h. The swelling is limited by the suture lines of the skull as the 
pericranium is fixed to the margins of the bone Option A: Tension in the swelling varies with crying in meningocele. Option C: Edematous fluid collects in caput succedaneum. Option D: Caput succedaneum may be present at birth. 63 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: The pediatrician notices a diffuse, reddish scalp swelling in a newborn born by vacuum 
extraction. Which of the following is not a characteristic of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of caput succedaneum which disappears within 2-3 days. In vertex presentation, labor forces alter the shape of the fetal head. In prolonged labor, before 
complete cervical dilatation, the portion of the fetal scalp immediately over the cervical os 
becomes edematous. A swelling is formed is due to the stagnation of fluid in the layers of the scalp 
beneath the girdle of contact. This is known as caput succedaneum. The swelling is diffuse, boggy, and not limited by the suture lines. It resolves spontaneously within 
2-3 days after birth. It is a result of the static position of the head for a long period of time. Chignon is a type of artificial caput succedaneum, which is a swelling produced on the fetal head 
because of the scalp getting sucked into the cup during vacuum extraction. 64 
Sold by @itachibot 65 
Sold by @itachibot Placenta and Fetal Membranes
